10870Journal of Chemical CrystallographyJ Chem Crystallogr1074-15421572-8854Kluwer Academic Publishers-Plenum PublishersNew Yorks10870-006-9117-1911710.1007/s10870-006-9117-1ArticleThe synthesis and crystal structure of a new coordination polymeric adduct containing mercury iodideNiuYunyin1aHanChunliang2ZhangHongyun1YangGuang1ZhuYu1Department of ChemistryZhengzhou University450052HenanChinaDepartment of ChemistryHenna Institute of Education450014HenanChinaniuyy@zzu.edu.cn306200610200636106796841620063220061620063062006© Springer Science+Business Media, Inc. 20062006

A new organic-inorganic hybrid adduct, [HgI2(dps)]n (dps=4,4′-dipyridylsulfide), has been synthesized by the reaction of HgI2 with dps in THF at room temperature. The structure characterization was performed by means of IR, elemental analyses and single crystal X-ray analysis. It crystallizes in space group P2(1)/c with a=5.5522(1) Å, b=12.127(2) Å, c=21.508(4) Å, β=91.84(3)°. The structure consists of distorted tetrahedral Hg(II) centers bridged by dps ligands to form one-dimensional linear chains with C–H···I interaction. Comparison of transition metal assemblies with dps showed that the dimensionality and structure of self-assembled supramolecule depend on the coordination preferences of metal ions, the geometry, bulk, and rigidity of ligands, the number and size of anions, and the supramolecular weak interactions.

Crystallographic data for the structure reported in this article has been deposited in the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center, CCDC No. 285579 for compound 1. The information may be obtained free of charge from the Director, CCDC, 12 Union Road, Cambridge, CB2 1EZ, UK (fax: +44-1223-336033; e-mail: deposit@ccdc.cam.ac.uk or http://www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk).

Introduction

Recent interest in the use of bipyridyl-based bridging ligands and transition metallates in the preparation of various extended architectures stems from the recognition that these polymeric frameworks possess potentially useful properties such as use as catalysts,1 conductivity,2,3 magnetism,4 and nonlinear optics.5 Our emphasis has been placed on designing and constructing bipyridyl-based self-assemblies with metal halides and investigating their possible bonding modes and properties.6,7 Although HgX2 (X=Cl, Br) assemblies with bipyridyl ligands are plentiful,8–10 the mercury iodide adducts with bipyridyl-based bridging ligands are relatively unexplored. We have reported some crystal structures of this type from the self-assembly of HgI2 with the corresponding bipyridyl-based ligands such as N,N′-bis(4-pyridylmethyl)-piperazine,11 4,4′-azopyridine,12 and N,N′-bis(4-pyridyl formamide)-1,4-benzene).13 Described herein is the preparation and characterization of a new polymeric HgI2 adduct with dps, which is an ideal angular ligand for its N,N′-bidentate mode and N,N′, S-tridentate mode14 (Scheme 1), but remains largely unexplored as a bridging ligand.15–27 The compound was found to exhibit 1D linear polymeric structure for the tetrahedral preference of Hg, the flexibility of dps, the steric effect from I− group, and the interchain C–H···I interactions.

Experimental

4,4′-dipyridylsulfide was obtained from Aldrich. All the other chemicals were of A. R. Grade and used without further purification. IR spectra were recorded with a Shimazu IR435 spectrometer in the region of 400–4000 cm−1 with pressed KBr pellets. Carbon, hydrogen and nitrogen analyses were performed with a Perkin-Elmer 240C instrument.

Synthesis of [HgI<sub>2</sub>(dps)]<sub><italic>n</italic></sub> (<bold>1</bold>)

A THF solution (5 ml) of HgI2 (45 mg, 0.1 mmol) was mixed carefully with a THF solution (5 ml) of dps (37 mg, 0.2 mmol) and filtered. The filtrate was then maintained undisturbed at ambient temperature and colorless crystals (40% yield) suitable for X-ray diffraction were obtained two days later. Anal. Calc. for C10H8 HgI2N2S: C, 18.69; H, 1.25; N, 4.36 Found: C, 18.30; H, 1.67; N, 4.41. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 1579(s), 1476(w), 1411(m), 1214(w), 1062(w), 1007(w), 818(w), 714(w), 534(w).

Crystal structure determination

Crystallographic data for the title compound were collected using Mo-Ka radiation (λ=0.71073 Å) on a Rigaku RAXIS-IV image plate area detector. The data were corrected for Lorentz and polarization factors and for absorption by using empirical scan data. The structure was solved with the SHELX program,28 and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods based on F2, with anisotropic thermal parameters for the non-hydrogen atoms. The hydrogen atoms were located theoretically and not refined. Crystal data are summarized in detail in Table 1. Selected bond lengths, bond angles and final atomic parameters are put in Tables 2 and 3.

Results and discussionCrystal structure of [HgI<sub>2</sub>(dps)]<sub><italic>n</italic></sub>

Figure 1 shows an ORTEP diagram of the asymmetric unit and atom labeling scheme for [HgI2(dps)]n. Its local geometry consists of a distorted tetrahedral arrangement at each Hg atom, which comprises two iodide ions and two nitrogen atoms from two dps ligands. The Hg–I1, Hg–I2, and Hg–N1, Hg(1)–N(2)#1 bond lengths are 2.666(1), 2.653(1), and 2.44(1), 2.40(1) Å, respectively, which are similar to those of the related polymers [HgI2(L)]n11–13 (Hg–I ranging from 2.6430(5) to 2.6683(8) Å, and Hg–N from 2.3626(6) to 2.457(6) Å) and are all within normal values. The deviation from tetrahedral geometry may be attributed to the strong preference of Hg for soft donors such as the iodine atoms with large atomic size and the weak preference for N atoms.29,30 This argument is supported by the fact that the I–Hg–I bond angles [144.83(4)°] are larger than the N–Hg–N bond angles [103.4(4)°]. Our studies showed that the HgI2 polymeric adducts with rigid bipyridyl ligands often exhibit zigzag structures11–13 and the main reasons come from three packing effects: (1) the steric effect of the iodide group, (2) the rigid of the ligand, and (3) the preference of Hg for tetrahedral coordination geometry. Compared with the one-dimensional linear polymeric structure {[HgI2(bpp)]}n(bpp = 1, 3-bis(4-pyridyl)propane,31 it is probable that the flexibility of dps dominate the final solid state structure since the changeability of the spacer C–S–C angle in dps make this ligand an adaptable organic block for polymer assemblies.

Among the available complexes of dps, the C–S–C angles range from 100.1–107.9° (Table 4). In title compound dps ligand act as N,N′-bidentate ligand and the C(8)–S(1)–C(3) is 101.4(6)°. Based on the information in Table 4, metals preferring high coordination numbers often tend to form polymeric structures with high dimensionality, such as Co2+ complexes with 1-2D structures, and Cu+ and Ag+ complexes with 1-2D architectures. Whereas Zn2+ and Hg2+ complexes exhibit 0-1D structures for their tetrahedral preferences. So the metal ions’ selection plays important role in the self-assembly reaction and has remarkable effect on the final dimensionality of polymeric complexes. The secondary factor is the number and size of terminal anions, the more they are the simple the structure is; such as the related Ag complexes, [Ag(NO3)3(dps)2·2H2O]n,14 [Ag2(dps)2(ClO4)2·(MeCN)]n,15 and [Ag2(dps)2(MeCN)3(ClO4)2·H2O]n15 are 1D structures, whereas [Ag(dps)2(PF6)]n,19 [Ag(dps)2(CF3SO3)]n,19 and [Ag(dps)2·BF4]n20 are 2D. Another examples are [Co(dps)2(NCS)2·2H2O]n (1D) and [Co(dps)2Cl2]n (2D):25 the NCS− has bigger size and steric effect than Cl−, and seems to be an obstacle to form 2D sheet. So in 1 the size of I− group also facilitates the formation of the final polymeric chain.

Another interesting feature of 1 is the existence of interchain C–H···I interaction in molecular packing (Fig. 2); as a kind of subtle factors in crystal engineering, C–H···X interactions (or hydrogen bonding) play important role on the solid state structure of supramolecules.32,33 In the structure of 1 the C···I distances of 3.884 Å and 3.958 Å, and the corresponding C–H···I angles are 135.48° and 148.23°, respectively. All data are comparable to the values attributed to this type of interaction (C···I=3.81–3.98 Å, C–H···I=134–158°).33–37 For 1 although the C···I distances are outside the sum of normalized non-bonded contact radii [carbon (1.75 Å) and iodine (2.00 Å)], as has been pointed out, these types of interactions should not be thought of as van der Waals contacts, but as electrostatic attractions whose viability as a function of distance falls off much more slowly.33 From Table 4, the relatively small C–S–C angle of 101.4° shows a possible impact of C–H···I interactions on the solid structure. So in 1, the flexibility of dps together with the weak interchain C–H···I interactions favor a more staggered stacking of the chains, and consequently a three dimensional supramolecular conformation.

Conclusion

All the results indicate that it is very important to choose building blocks for the construction of supramolecular structures. A conclusion can be drawn that the dimensionality and structure of self-assembled supramolecule depend mainly on three aspects: the coordination preferences of metal ion, the geometry, bulk, and rigidity of ligands, and the number and size of anions. So, if we want a self-assembly with complicated architecture, high coordination-number metal ion, multifunctional, flexible ligand, and skimpy anions is advisable in synthesis process. Of course, weak interactions are also crucial factors for crystal packing, although they are serendipitous.

So in 1 the size of I- group also facilitates the formation of the final polymeric chain. Another interesting feature of 1 is the existence of interchain C-H⋅⋅⋅I interaction in molecular packing (Fig. 2); as a kind of subtle factors in crystal engineering, C-H⋅⋅⋅X interactions (or hydrogen bonding) play important role on the solid state structure of supramolecules.32,33 In the structure of 1 the C⋅⋅⋅I distances of 3.884 Å and 3.958 Å, and the corresponding C-H⋅⋅⋅I angles are 135.48° and 148.23°, respectively. All data are comparable to the values attributed to this type of interaction (C⋅⋅⋅I=3.81-3.98 Å, C-H⋅⋅⋅I=134-158°).33-37 For 1 although the C⋅⋅⋅I distances are outside the sum of normalized non-bonded contact radii [carbon (1.75 Å) and iodine (2.00 Å)], as has been pointed out, these types of interactions should not be thought of as van der Waals contacts, but as electrostatic attractions whose viability as a function of distance falls off much more slowly.33 From Table 4, the relatively small C-S-C angle of 101.4° shows a possible impact of C-H⋅⋅⋅I interactions on the solid structure. So in 1, the flexibility of dps together with the weak interchain C-H⋅⋅⋅I interactions favor a more staggered stacking of the chains, and consequently a three dimensional supramolecular conformation.ConclusionAll the results indicate that it is very important to choose building blocks for the construction of supramolecular structures. A conclusion can be drawn that the dimensionality and structure of self-assembled supramolecule depend mainly on three aspects: the coordination preferences of metal ion, the geometry, bulk, and rigidity of ligands, and the number and size of anions. So, if we want a self-assembly with complicated architecture, high coordination-number metal ion, multifunctional, flexible ligand, and skimpy anions is advisable in synthesis process. Of course, weak interactions are also crucial factors for crystal packing, although they are serendipitous.AcknowledgementsThis work is supported by the Henan Province Excellent Young Foundation (No. 0612002800) and the Chinese Postdoctoral Science Foundation (2003033525).References1.FujitaM.KwonY.J.WashizuS.OguraK.J. elements.content: A new organic-inorganic hybrid adduct, [HgI2(dps)]n (dps=4,4′-dipyridylsulfide), has been synthesized by the reaction of HgI2 with dps in THF at room temperature. The structure characterization was performed by means of IR, elemental analyses and single crystal X-ray analysis. It crystallizes in space group P2(1)/c with a=5.5522(1) Å, b=12.127(2) Å, c=21.508(4) Å, β=91.84(3)°. The structure consists of distorted tetrahedral Hg(II) centers bridged by dps ligands to form one-dimensional linear chains with C–H···I interaction. Comparison of transition metal assemblies with dps showed that the dimensionality and structure of self-assembled supramolecule depend on the coordination preferences of metal ions, the geometry, bulk, and rigidity of ligands, the number and size of anions, and the supramolecular weak interactions.

The structure characterization was performed by means of IR, elemental analyses and single crystal X-ray analysis. It crystallizes in space group P2(1)/c with a=5.5522(1) Å, b=12.127(2) Å, c=21.508(4) Å, β=91.84(3)°. The structure consists of distorted tetrahedral Hg(II) centers bridged by dps ligands to form one-dimensional linear chains with C-H⋅⋅⋅I interaction. Comparison of transition metal assemblies with dps showed that the dimensionality and structure of self-assembled supramolecule depend on the coordination preferences of metal ions, the geometry, bulk, and rigidity of ligands, the number and size of anions, and the supramolecular weak interactions.

elements.content: Recent interest in the use of bipyridyl-based bridging ligands and transition metallates in the preparation of various extended architectures stems from the recognition that these polymeric frameworks possess potentially useful properties such as use as catalysts,1 conductivity,2,3 magnetism,4 and nonlinear optics.5 Our emphasis has been placed on designing and constructing bipyridyl-based self-assemblies with metal halides and investigating their possible bonding modes and properties.6,7 Although HgX2 (X=Cl, Br) assemblies with bipyridyl ligands are plentiful,8–10 the mercury iodide adducts with bipyridyl-based bridging ligands are relatively unexplored. We have reported some crystal structures of this type from the self-assembly of HgI2 with the corresponding bipyridyl-based ligands such as N,N′-bis(4-pyridylmethyl)-piperazine,11 4,4′-azopyridine,12 and N,N′-bis(4-pyridyl formamide)-1,4-benzene).13 Described herein is the preparation and characterization of a new polymeric HgI2 adduct with dps, which is an ideal angular ligand for its N,N′-bidentate mode and N,N′, S-tridentate mode14 (Scheme 1), but remains largely unexplored as a bridging ligand.15–27 The compound was found to exhibit 1D linear polymeric structure for the tetrahedral preference of Hg, the flexibility of dps, the steric effect from I− group, and the interchain C–H···I interactions.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Recent interest in the use of bipyridyl-based bridging ligands and transition metallates in the preparation of various extended architectures stems from the recognition that these polymeric frameworks possess potentially useful properties such as use as catalysts,1 conductivity,2,3 magnetism,4 and nonlinear optics.5 Our emphasis has been placed on designing and constructing bipyridyl-based self-assemblies with metal halides and investigating their possible bonding modes and properties.6,7 Although HgX2 (X=Cl, Br) assemblies with bipyridyl ligands are plentiful,8-10 the mercury iodide adducts with bipyridyl-based bridging ligands are relatively unexplored. We have reported some crystal structures of this type from the self-assembly of HgI2 with the corresponding bipyridyl-based ligands such as N,N'-bis(4-pyridylmethyl)-piperazine,11 4,4'-azopyridine,12 and N,N'-bis(4-pyridyl formamide)-1,4-benzene).13 Described herein is the preparation and characterization of a new polymeric HgI2 adduct with dps, which is an ideal angular ligand for its N,N'-bidentate mode and N,N', S-tridentate mode14 (Scheme 1), but remains largely unexplored as a bridging ligand.15-27 The compound was found to exhibit 1D linear polymeric structure for the tetrahedral preference of Hg, the flexibility of dps, the steric effect from I- group, and the interchain C-H⋅⋅⋅I interactions.

Experimental

4,4'-dipyridylsulfide was obtained from Aldrich. All the other chemicals were of A. R. Grade and used without further purification. elements.content: Crystallographic data for the title compound were collected using Mo-Ka radiation (λ=0.71073 Å) on a Rigaku RAXIS-IV image plate area detector. The data were corrected for Lorentz and polarization factors and for absorption by using empirical scan data. The structure was solved with the SHELX program,28 and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods based on F2, with anisotropic thermal parameters for the non-hydrogen atoms. The hydrogen atoms were located theoretically and not refined. Crystal data are summarized in detail in Table 1. Selected bond lengths, bond angles and final atomic parameters are put in Tables 2 and 3.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal structure determination

Crystallographic data for the title compound were collected using Mo-Ka radiation (λ=0.71073 Å) on a Rigaku RAXIS-IV image plate area detector. The data were corrected for Lorentz and polarization factors and for absorption by using empirical scan data. The structure was solved with the SHELX program,28 and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods based on F2, with anisotropic thermal parameters for the non-hydrogen atoms. The hydrogen atoms were located theoretically and not refined. Crystal data are summarized in detail in Table 1. Selected bond lengths, bond angles and final atomic parameters are put in Tables 2 and 3.

Figure 1 shows an ORTEP diagram of the asymmetric unit and atom labeling scheme for [HgI2(dps)]n. Its local geometry consists of a distorted tetrahedral arrangement at each Hg atom, which comprises two iodide ions and two nitrogen atoms from two dps ligands. The Hg–I1, Hg–I2, and Hg–N1, Hg(1)–N(2)#1 bond lengths are 2.666(1), 2.653(1), and 2.44(1), 2.40(1) Å, respectively, which are similar to those of the related polymers [HgI2(L)]n11–13 (Hg–I ranging from 2.6430(5) to 2.6683(8) Å, and Hg–N from 2.3626(6) to 2.457(6) Å) and are all within normal values. The deviation from tetrahedral geometry may be attributed to the strong preference of Hg for soft donors such as the iodine atoms with large atomic size and the weak preference for N atoms.29,30 This argument is supported by the fact that the I–Hg–I bond angles [144.83(4)°] are larger than the N–Hg–N bond angles [103.4(4)°]. Our studies showed that the HgI2 polymeric adducts with rigid bipyridyl ligands often exhibit zigzag structures11–13 and the main reasons come from three packing effects: (1) the steric effect of the iodide group, (2) the rigid of the ligand, and (3) the preference of Hg for tetrahedral coordination geometry. Compared with the one-dimensional linear polymeric structure {[HgI2(bpp)]}n(bpp = 1, 3-bis(4-pyridyl)propane,31 it is probable that the flexibility of dps dominate the final solid state structure since the changeability of the spacer C–S–C angle in dps make this ligand an adaptable organic block for polymer assemblies.
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Crystal structure of [HgI2(dps)]n

Figure 1 shows an ORTEP diagram of the asymmetric unit and atom labeling scheme for [HgI2(dps)]n. Its local geometry consists of a distorted tetrahedral arrangement at each Hg atom, which comprises two iodide ions and two nitrogen atoms from two dps ligands. The Hg-I1, Hg-I2, and Hg-N1, Hg(1)-N(2)#1 bond lengths are 2.666(1), 2.653(1), and 2.44(1), 2.40(1) Å, respectively, which are similar to those of the related polymers [HgI2(L)]n11-13 (Hg-I ranging from 2.6430(5) to 2.6683(8) Å, and Hg-N from 2.3626(6) to 2.457(6) Å) and are all within normal values. The deviation from tetrahedral geometry may be attributed to the strong preference of Hg for soft donors such as the iodine atoms with large atomic size and the weak preference for N atoms.29,30 This argument is supported by the fact that the I-Hg-I bond angles [144.83(4)°] are larger than the N-Hg-N bond angles [103.4(4)°]. Our studies showed that the HgI2 polymeric adducts with rigid bipyridyl ligands often exhibit zigzag structures11-13 and the main reasons come from three packing effects: (1) the steric effect of the iodide group, (2) the rigid of the ligand, and (3) the preference of Hg for tetrahedral coordination geometry. Compared with the one-dimensional linear polymeric structure {[HgI2(bpp)]}n(bpp = 1, 3-bis(4-pyridyl)propane,31 it is probable that the flexibility of dps dominate the final solid state structure since the changeability of the spacer C-S-C angle in dps make this ligand an adaptable organic block for polymer assemblies.

elements.content: Among the available complexes of dps, the C–S–C angles range from 100.1–107.9° (Table 4). In title compound dps ligand act as N,N′-bidentate ligand and the C(8)–S(1)–C(3) is 101.4(6)°. Based on the information in Table 4, metals preferring high coordination numbers often tend to form polymeric structures with high dimensionality, such as Co2+ complexes with 1-2D structures, and Cu+ and Ag+ complexes with 1-2D architectures. Whereas Zn2+ and Hg2+ complexes exhibit 0-1D structures for their tetrahedral preferences. So the metal ions’ selection plays important role in the self-assembly reaction and has remarkable effect on the final dimensionality of polymeric complexes. The secondary factor is the number and size of terminal anions, the more they are the simple the structure is; such as the related Ag complexes, [Ag(NO3)3(dps)2·2H2O]n,14 [Ag2(dps)2(ClO4)2·(MeCN)]n,15 and [Ag2(dps)2(MeCN)3(ClO4)2·H2O]n15 are 1D structures, whereas [Ag(dps)2(PF6)]n,19 [Ag(dps)2(CF3SO3)]n,19 and [Ag(dps)2·BF4]n20 are 2D. Another examples are [Co(dps)2(NCS)2·2H2O]n (1D) and [Co(dps)2Cl2]n (2D):25 the NCS− has bigger size and steric effect than Cl−, and seems to be an obstacle to form 2D sheet. So in 1 the size of I− group also facilitates the formation of the final polymeric chain.

elements.content: Another interesting feature of 1 is the existence of interchain C–H···I interaction in molecular packing (Fig. 2); as a kind of subtle factors in crystal engineering, C–H···X interactions (or hydrogen bonding) play important role on the solid state structure of supramolecules.32,33 In the structure of 1 the C···I distances of 3.884 Å and 3.958 Å, and the corresponding C–H···I angles are 135.48° and 148.23°, respectively. All data are comparable to the values attributed to this type of interaction (C···I=3.81–3.98 Å, C–H···I=134–158°).33–37 For 1 although the C···I distances are outside the sum of normalized non-bonded contact radii [carbon (1.75 Å) and iodine (2.00 Å)], as has been pointed out, these types of interactions should not be thought of as van der Waals contacts, but as electrostatic attractions whose viability as a function of distance falls off much more slowly.33 From Table 4, the relatively small C–S–C angle of 101.4° shows a possible impact of C–H···I interactions on the solid structure. So in 1, the flexibility of dps together with the weak interchain C–H···I interactions favor a more staggered stacking of the chains, and consequently a three dimensional supramolecular conformation.
elements.clean_text: Another interesting feature of 1 is the existence of interchain C-H⋅⋅⋅I interaction in molecular packing (Fig. 2); as a kind of subtle factors in crystal engineering, C-H⋅⋅⋅X interactions (or hydrogen bonding) play important role on the solid state structure of supramolecules.32,33 In the structure of 1 the C⋅⋅⋅I distances of 3.884 Å and 3.958 Å, and the corresponding C-H⋅⋅⋅I angles are 135.48° and 148.23°, respectively. All data are comparable to the values attributed to this type of interaction (C⋅⋅⋅I=3.81-3.98 Å, C-H⋅⋅⋅I=134-158°).33-37 For 1 although the C⋅⋅⋅I distances are outside the sum of normalized non-bonded contact radii [carbon (1.75 Å) and iodine (2.00 Å)], as has been pointed out, these types of interactions should not be thought of as van der Waals contacts, but as electrostatic attractions whose viability as a function of distance falls off much more slowly.33 From Table 4, the relatively small C-S-C angle of 101.4° shows a possible impact of C-H⋅⋅⋅I interactions on the solid structure. So in 1, the flexibility of dps together with the weak interchain C-H⋅⋅⋅I interactions favor a more staggered stacking of the chains, and consequently a three dimensional supramolecular conformation.

elements.content: All the results indicate that it is very important to choose building blocks for the construction of supramolecular structures. A conclusion can be drawn that the dimensionality and structure of self-assembled supramolecule depend mainly on three aspects: the coordination preferences of metal ion, the geometry, bulk, and rigidity of ligands, and the number and size of anions. So, if we want a self-assembly with complicated architecture, high coordination-number metal ion, multifunctional, flexible ligand, and skimpy anions is advisable in synthesis process. Of course, weak interactions are also crucial factors for crystal packing, although they are serendipitous.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

All the results indicate that it is very important to choose building blocks for the construction of supramolecular structures. A conclusion can be drawn that the dimensionality and structure of self-assembled supramolecule depend mainly on three aspects: the coordination preferences of metal ion, the geometry, bulk, and rigidity of ligands, and the number and size of anions. So, if we want a self-assembly with complicated architecture, high coordination-number metal ion, multifunctional, flexible ligand, and skimpy anions is advisable in synthesis process. Of course, weak interactions are also crucial factors for crystal packing, although they are serendipitous.

cln_elements.content:
A new organic-inorganic hybrid adduct, [HgI2(dps)]n (dps=4,4′-dipyridylsulfide), has been synthesized by the reaction of HgI2 with dps in THF at room temperature. The structure characterization was performed by means of IR, elemental analyses and single crystal X-ray analysis. It crystallizes in space group P2(1)/c with a=5.5522(1) Å, b=12.127(2) Å, c=21.508(4) Å, β=91.84(3)°. The structure consists of distorted tetrahedral Hg(II) centers bridged by dps ligands to form one-dimensional linear chains with C–H···I interaction. Comparison of transition metal assemblies with dps showed that the dimensionality and structure of self-assembled supramolecule depend on the coordination preferences of metal ions, the geometry, bulk, and rigidity of ligands, the number and size of anions, and the supramolecular weak interactions.

Synthesis of [HgI<sub>2</sub>(dps)]<sub><italic>n</italic></sub> (<bold>1</bold>)

A THF solution (5 ml) of HgI2 (45 mg, 0.1 mmol) was mixed carefully with a THF solution (5 ml) of dps (37 mg, 0.2 mmol) and filtered. The filtrate was then maintained undisturbed at ambient temperature and colorless crystals (40% yield) suitable for X-ray diffraction were obtained two days later. Anal. Calc. for C10H8 HgI2N2S: C, 18.69; H, 1.25; N, 4.36 Found: C, 18.30; H, 1.67; N, 4.41. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 1579(s), 1476(w), 1411(m), 1214(w), 1062(w), 1007(w), 818(w), 714(w), 534(w).
